doc.after: The demobilisation plan was put into action on 16Â August 1945, the day after Japan surrendered.[1] At this time the military had a strength of 598,300 men and women. Of these, 310,600 were in Australia, 224,000 were serving in the South West Pacific Area (SWPA) and 20,100 were in Britain and other parts of the world.[5] The only personnel to be discharged during August and September were former prisoners of war and those with a long period of service, however, as general demobilisation did not begin until 1Â October 1945. During the intervening months dispersal centres were established in each state and territory's capital city. These centres were to provide information on employment, land settlement, housing, training, loans, tools for trades and other benefits for service personnel as their discharges were processed.[6] Lieutenant-General Stanley Savige was appointed the Coordinator of Demobilisation and Dispersal in September.[7]
